course.name: Done is better - Build What Matters

questions.question: You have an idea you have invested in. How should you treat it?
options: Define a kill criterion: we stop if [observable condition]; run the test; stop investing when it fails
Double down and invest more regardless of evidence or test results that show it is failing
Hide the results if they are negative to avoid admitting failure or making changes
Extend the timeline indefinitely until the idea eventually succeeds without validation

questions.question: A team tests a new feature with 100 users. After two weeks, only 2% use it. They decide to stop investing and move resources elsewhere. What does this demonstrate?
options: Killing early: stopping bad or wrong ideas as soon as evidence shows they do not work
Cancelling all projects regardless of evidence or outcomes
Firing people early in the project without proper evaluation
Cutting budget only and not scope or deliverables

questions.question: Why define a kill criterion before running the test?
options: So you know when to stop investing; otherwise sunk cost takes over and wastes resources
To please stakeholders by appearing thorough and well-planned
To look rigorous and professional without actually using it
It is optional and not necessary for making good decisions

questions.question: Sunk cost (continuing because we already invested) leads to:
options: More waste; you keep investing in an idea that evidence says is wrong
Faster payoff through continued investment
Higher commitment to the original plan
No significant downside in most business cases

questions.question: Treating killing an idea as personal failure can result in:
options: Keeping bad ideas alive and wasting resources
Better ideas
Higher morale
No meaningful effect on outcomes

questions.question: When should you check the kill criterion?
options: At a set time or signal; decide when you will check before you start the work
Only at the end when all resources have been invested and it is too late to pivot
When someone asks about progress or results without a predetermined schedule
Never; kill criteria are not meant to be actually used or enforced

questions.question: For one idea or project, what should you write down?
options: The kill criterion: we stop if [observable condition]; and when you will check it
Only the success criteria without defining when to stop if it fails or shows no progress
Only the budget without criteria for when to stop investing if evidence contradicts
Only the deadline without conditions for killing the project if it is not working
